name: PolicyGPT Experiment
instructions: Below is a AI-generated policy question, along with answers from two different AI models. Choose the answer you prefer.

## Question
[Policy #201](https://policy.rice.edu/201)

If an Associate Professor is hired without tenure, can their initial appointment exceed 3 years? What happens if they are not awarded tenure by the end of the 7th year?

options.text:
An initial appointment for an associate professor without tenure cannot exceed three years. If the appointment is renewed, the total time in tenure-track faculty ranks without tenure must not exceed eight years, excluding leaves that stop the tenure clock.

If an associate professor is not awarded tenure by the end of the seventh year, the eighth year becomes the final year in the tenure-track faculty ranks. No review for tenure is made in the contract’s final year, and the person cannot be appointed to any other tenure-track faculty rank.

According to section 3.a.2.a, an associate professor or a professor who was initially appointed without tenure may be reviewed for tenure at any time during the first seven years, but no later. If they are not awarded tenure by the end of the seventh year, the eighth year is the final year in the tenure-track faculty ranks.

The initial appointment without tenure for the rank of associate professor or professor must not exceed three years (as stated in section 3.a.2.a).

## Question
[Policy #201](https://policy.rice.edu/201)

For teaching professor ranks, is there a limit on the number of years someone can spend at the Assistant rank before being promoted or dismissed? What extensions are permitted?

options.text:
Yes, there is a limit on the number of years someone can spend at the Assistant rank in the teaching professor ranks. Assistant teaching professors are expected to be promoted after, usually, six years at rank. Failure to be promoted from assistant teaching professor to associate teaching professor results in dismissal from the teaching professor ranks.

Extensions to this time at the assistant rank are permitted in certain circumstances. Medical leaves, including leaves for pregnancy and childbirth, are instances that may extend this time. Additionally, family leave or medical leave during the academic semester may also lead to an extension of the contract terms and promotion clock by up to one year, with a maximum of two extensions per contract.

In the teaching professor ranks, appointments are usually nine-month, full-time positions with contracts for two to three years at the assistant rank. However, medical leaves, including pregnancy and childbirth leaves, may extend this time. Failure to be promoted from assistant teaching professor results in dismissal from the ranks.

While there is no explicit limit on the number of years someone can spend at the Assistant rank, failure to be promoted after six years (accounting for medical leave extensions) typically results in dismissal. The "Procedures for Appointments for Teaching Professor Ranks" note this expectation, implying a general time frame for promotion.

## Question
[Policy #201](https://policy.rice.edu/201)

Can a faculty member take a paid sabbatical leave before being reviewed for tenure? What are the eligibility requirements?

options.text:
Yes, a faculty member can take a paid sabbatical leave before being reviewed for tenure. Specifically, an assistant professor who is reappointed is eligible for a one-semester junior faculty leave, which is a form of paid leave. This junior faculty leave can be taken at any time following a successful reappointment but not later than the semester immediately prior to the one in which they will be reviewed for promotion to associate professor with tenure by the P&T Committee.

The eligibility requirements for taking a sabbatical leave include:
1. Completion of eight years of service, including the one semester of junior paid leave provided by policy.
2. Accumulation of at least six semesters of service credit, as six semesters of credit is the minimum draw down for any sabbatical leave.
3. Approval of the sabbatical request is subject to satisfactory performance and productivity in scholarship, creative activity, and teaching.

Additionally, the sabbatical leave must be authorized based on the recommendation of the Chairperson of a department, with the approval of the appropriate Dean, the Provost, the President, and the Board of Trustees.

According to the policy, a faculty member's eligibility for a sabbatical leave is contingent on their satisfactory performance and productivity in scholarship, creative activity, and teaching. However, it does not explicitly state whether a paid sabbatical leave can be taken before being reviewed for tenure.

The policy notes that leaves of absence without pay are not counted in the eight-year limitation on service for untenured, tenure-track professors if the faculty member is unable to continue normal scholarly activities during that period. This suggests that unpaid leaves may have implications for the tenure review process, but it does not address paid sabbatical leaves.

To determine whether a faculty member can take a paid sabbatical leave before being reviewed for tenure, additional information about their specific circumstances and the department's policies would be needed. 

However, the policy does state that Assistant Professors will be eligible to request their first sabbatical leave with the completion of eight years of service including one semester of junior paid leave provided by policy 201, which governs their appointment.

## Question
[Policy #201](https://policy.rice.edu/201)

Under what circumstances can an Associate Professor with tenure be dismissed before retirement? What process must be followed?

options.text:
An Associate Professor with tenure can be dismissed before retirement only for cause. Adequate cause for dismissal must be directly and substantially related to the fitness of the faculty member in their professional capacities as a teacher or scholar. Examples of behavior that may justify dismissal include failure to perform duties, fiscal malfeasance, plagiarism, dishonest research, and sexual harassment. Dismissal will not be used to restrain faculty members in their exercise of academic freedom or other rights under U.S. law.

The process for dismissal involves several steps:
1. **Initiation of Proceedings**: The president or the president's delegate initiates the consideration of dismissal by presenting a written statement of the allegations to the speaker of the Faculty Senate. This statement must be framed with reasonable particularity and justify dismissal if established.
2. **Formal Hearing**: The faculty member will be dismissed for cause only after having an opportunity for a formal hearing by a faculty Hearing Panel convened for this purpose. The Faculty Senate, in consultation with the president, establishes the procedure for dismissal hearings. The hearing must ensure written notice of the allegations, the presumption of fitness until proven otherwise, confidentiality, an unbiased panel, and the opportunity for the faculty member to be present, confront and question witnesses, and provide information in their favor.
3. **Report of Findings**: Following the hearing, the panel will weigh the evidence and provide a written report containing its findings and recommendations to the president. The president will then inform the Board of Trustees of the decision.

Additionally, pending a final report by the hearing panel, the administration may temporarily suspend the accused faculty member if their continuance threatens harm to others, the accused, university property, or operations. The faculty member will receive full salary during the suspension period.

According to section 8.a.1, a tenured faculty member, including an Associate Professor, can only be dismissed for cause related to their professional capacity as a teacher or scholar. Dismissal due to discontinuance or reduction of programs or departments is an exception, as stated in section 8.c.

If the dismissal is not related to program discontinuance or reduction, it must be based on adequate cause directly and substantially detracting from the faculty member's professional capacity.

The termination process for tenured faculty members is not explicitly outlined, but sections 5.f. Termination process and 5.d. Retirement process suggest that a separate procedure applies for non-tenured faculty.

## Question
[Policy #201](https://policy.rice.edu/201)

For faculty in research professor ranks, what types of leaves are permitted? Can a leave extend the promotion clock?

options.text:
Faculty in the research professor ranks at Rice University are permitted several types of leaves, including primary caregiver leaves, unpaid sabbatical/professional leaves, and paid parental leave (PPL). 

Primary caregiver leaves and unpaid sabbatical/professional leaves may, under certain circumstances, extend the promotion clock for faculty in the research professor ranks. Additionally, faculty members who take a paid parental leave (PPL) can request an extension on the promotion clock and contract terms. Such requests should be made to the Vice Provost of Academic Affairs no later than thirty days after returning from PPL, and if granted, the clock and contract will be extended by one year. Faculty members granted extensions as a result of PPL may receive a maximum of two promotion clock extensions for each rank.

Faculty in the research professor ranks are eligible for primary caregiver leaves and unpaid sabbatical/professional leaves. Leaves for this rank may, under certain circumstances, extend the promotion clock.

## Question

In section 3g, it states that 'The faculty member will be afforded an opportunity to obtain necessary witnesses and documentary or other evidence.' Does this mean the university has to provide funding for the faculty member to hire expert witnesses or investigators to gather evidence on their behalf?

options.text: The information provided in the snippets does not specify that the university is required to provide funding for the faculty member to hire expert witnesses or investigators to gather evidence on their behalf. Section 3g states that the faculty member will have the opportunity to obtain necessary witnesses and evidence, but it does not mention any obligation on the part of the university to fund these efforts.

According to section 2 of the policy, it states that "Throughout the investigation, the burden of proof and the burden of gathering evidence sufficient to reach a determination regarding responsibility rest on the University, not on either party." This suggests that the university is responsible for gathering evidence, but it does not explicitly state whether they are also responsible for providing funding for expert witnesses or investigators.

However, section 3i mentions that "The Hearing Panel will reserve the right...to meet in closed session outside the presence of the parties or their representatives", which implies that the panel may have some level of control over who is present during the investigation. But it does not provide any information about funding for expert witnesses or investigators.

Therefore, answering is not possible given the available information.

## Question
[Policy #201a](https://policy.rice.edu/201a)

The policy outlines a process with three potential stages. Under what circumstances would the first two informal stages (initial assessment/settlement and Appeals & Grievances inquiry) be bypassed and the process move directly to the third formal hearing stage?

options.text: The first two informal stages (initial assessment/settlement and Appeals & Grievances inquiry) may be bypassed and the process move directly to the third formal hearing stage in cases involving allegations of sexual harassment or research misconduct. In such instances, the procedures outlined in Rice Policy 830 for sexual harassment and Rice Policy 324 for research misconduct will be followed, which may lead directly to the third stage: the formal hearing.

The first two informal stages (Initial Assessment and Attempt at Mutual Settlement, and Appeals and Grievances Inquiry) can be bypassed and the process moved directly to the third formal hearing stage if a mutual settlement is not reached after the initial assessment. However, it's also possible for the process to move directly to the third stage in cases where research misconduct is alleged, as Rice Policy 324 describes separate steps and procedures for such cases.

Additionally, if additional allegations or charges are added at a later date, and these new allegations meet the threshold for formal disciplinary action, then the process may proceed to the third stage without going through the informal stages.

## Question
[Policy #201a](https://policy.rice.edu/201a)

In section 3i, it states the hearing procedures 'have the aim of efficiently obtaining the truth, insuring fairness and confidentiality, and according dignity to all parties and witnesses.' How can confidentiality be maintained if lawyers are permitted to be present as stated in 3c?

options.text: Confidentiality during the hearing process can still be maintained even with the presence of lawyers, as the procedures are designed to ensure that all participants, including legal counsel, adhere to strict guidelines that protect the privacy of the proceedings. According to section 3c, the hearing will be presided over by the chair of the panel, who will establish the guidelines for the hearing, control the hearing, and ensure that lawyers do not overstep the bounds of what is appropriate in a hearing conducted by faculty colleagues in the efficient pursuit of truth. Additionally, the investigatory process is intended to be confidential, and reasonable and appropriate steps are taken to protect the confidentiality of the proceedings, participants, and evidence gathered. This ensures that the presence of lawyers does not compromise the confidentiality of the hearing.

The policy acknowledges a potential tension between maintaining confidentiality and allowing lawyers to attend the hearing. However, it appears that the chair of the panel will have discretion to control the hearing and ensure that the presence of lawyers does not compromise confidentiality.

In fact, section (3c) states that the chair will "keep lawyers, if present, from overstepping the bounds of what the panel believes is appropriate in a hearing conducted by faculty colleagues in the efficient pursuit of truth." This suggests that measures can be taken to maintain confidentiality even with lawyers present.

## Question
[Policy #201a](https://policy.rice.edu/201a)

If the Hearing Panel recommends dismissal but the President wishes to impose a less severe sanction, what is the process for the President to make that decision according to section 3n?

options.text: If the Hearing Panel recommends dismissal but the President wishes to impose a less severe sanction, the President must state the reasons for rejecting the findings of fact or recommendations of sanction in writing to the Hearing Panel, the accused, and the Speaker of the Faculty Senate. The President must also provide an opportunity for response from the panel and the faculty member before rendering a final decision. Additionally, if the President concludes that there are issues that have not been fully or adequately addressed, they may refer the matter back to the panel for additional hearings.

If the Hearing Panel recommends dismissal, but the President wishes to impose a less severe sanction, they will state their reasons in writing to the Hearing Panel, the accused faculty member, and the Speaker of the Faculty Senate. The President will provide an opportunity for response from the panel and the faculty member before rendering a final decision.

## Question
[Policy #201a](https://policy.rice.edu/201a)

According to section 3f, what responsibilities does the President's designate have related to gathering evidence and witnesses for the hearing?

options.text:
According to section 3f, the President's designate has several responsibilities related to gathering evidence and witnesses for the hearing. These responsibilities include:

1. Contacting potential witnesses deemed to have information material to the charges.
2. Gathering as much information and as many documents as they think relevant to prepare for the hearing.
3. Contacting potential witnesses in addition to those named by the administration or the accused.
4. Assisting the panel in obtaining witnesses or other evidence that the panel may wish as part of its hearing on the charges.

According to Section 3f, the President's designate has several key responsibilities:

*   Prior to the hearing, they must contact potential witnesses deemed to have information material to the charges.
*   They will gather as much information and documents as relevant to prepare for the hearing.
*   They may also contact additional witnesses beyond those named by the administration or the accused.
*   The designate has the responsibility to assist the panel in obtaining any additional evidence or witnesses that the panel wishes to consider during the hearing.

## Question
[Policy #201b](https://policy.rice.edu/201b)

The policy mentions that faculty should 'exercise appropriate restraint' when speaking as citizens. What specific types of speech would be considered a violation of this principle? Is there any guidance on determining what constitutes 'appropriate restraint'?

options.text:
The policy does not provide a detailed list of specific types of speech that would be considered a violation of the principle of 'appropriate restraint' when faculty speak as citizens. However, it does offer some guidance on the general expectations and limits of this principle.

According to the policy, faculty members should remember that the public may judge their profession and their institution by their utterances. Therefore, they should always be accurate, exercise appropriate restraint, show respect for the opinions of others, and make every effort to indicate that they are not speaking for the institution. This implies that speech that is inaccurate, disrespectful, or misleading about representing the institution could be considered a violation of this principle.

Additionally, the policy emphasizes that while faculty members are entitled to freedom in the classroom and in their research, they should be careful not to introduce into their teaching controversial matter which has no relation to their subject. This suggests that speech that is irrelevant to the academic subject being taught and is controversial could also be seen as failing to exercise appropriate restraint.

Overall, the guidance on what constitutes 'appropriate restraint' includes being accurate, respectful, and clear about not representing the institution, as well as avoiding the introduction of unrelated controversial matters in academic settings.

According to the provided documents, exercising "appropriate restraint" is mentioned in the context of freedom of expression for faculty members who speak as citizens. However, specific types of speech that would be considered a violation of this principle are not explicitly outlined.

The document emphasizes the importance of considering secondary social and ethical responsibilities, such as civility and mutual respect, when exercising free expression. It also notes that using slurs and epithets intended to discredit another's race, ethnic group, religion, or sex is not acceptable.

Regarding guidance on determining what constitutes "appropriate restraint," the policy does not provide specific criteria for assessing this principle. Instead, it highlights the need for faculty members to exercise self-restraint without which freedom of expression cannot flourish.

## Question
[Policy #201b](https://policy.rice.edu/201b)

The policy states that classroom discussion should avoid 'controversial matter which has no relation to their subject'. How is 'relation to the subject' determined, especially for subjects that intersect with societal issues? Is there any formal process for judging whether a topic is too far removed from the course material?

options.text:
The policy does not provide a detailed formal process for determining whether a topic is too far removed from the course material. However, it emphasizes that teachers should be careful not to introduce controversial matter which has no relation to their subject. This implies that the relevance of a topic to the subject matter should be judged based on its direct connection to the course content and objectives. 

For subjects that intersect with societal issues, the policy suggests that teachers should exercise appropriate restraint and ensure that their discussions are pertinent to the subject they are teaching. The American Association of University Professors (AAUP) acknowledges the need for restraint and emphasizes that teachers should be accurate, exercise appropriate restraint, show respect for the opinions of others, and make every effort to indicate that they are not speaking for the institution when discussing controversial matters.

In summary, while there is no formal process outlined, the determination of whether a topic is related to the subject should be guided by the principles of relevance to the course content, accuracy, and respect for differing opinions.

According to the policy, limitations on academic freedom due to religious or other aims of the institution should be clearly stated in writing at the time of appointment. However, it does not specify a formal process for determining whether a topic is "too far removed" from the course material.

The policy also states that classroom discussions should avoid introducing controversial matter unrelated to the subject, but it provides no guidance on how to make this determination.

In cases where subjects intersect with societal issues, the policy's focus on avoiding controversy unrelated to the subject may create ambiguity. The policy does not provide a clear framework for navigating these situations, leaving room for interpretation and potential conflict.

## Question
[Policy #201b](https://policy.rice.edu/201b)

For the research component of academic freedom, what exactly constitutes 'adequate performance of other academic duties'? Is there a specific threshold or percentage of workload that must be dedicated to teaching/service before pursuing additional research?

options.text: The concept of 'adequate performance of other academic duties' in the context of academic freedom and research is addressed in the AAUP's "1940 Statement of Principles." According to this statement, teachers are entitled to full freedom in research and in the publication of the results, provided that this research does not interfere with the adequate performance of their other academic duties. However, the statement does not specify a precise threshold or percentage of workload that must be dedicated to teaching or service before pursuing additional research.

The documents do not provide a specific threshold or percentage of workload for adequate performance of other academic duties. However, it is stated that "Teachers are entitled to full freedom in research and in the publication of the results, subject to the adequate performance of their other academic duties." This suggests that the institution expects faculty members to meet their teaching and service responsibilities before pursuing additional research.

Institutional Responsibilities include scholarly inquiry, Research, publishing scholarly work, teaching, preparing coursework, counseling students, and other work done for or on behalf of the University relevant to their academic discipline. 

It is also mentioned that "research professors are eligible to serve on university standing committees and department and school committees," which implies that research activities can coexist with other academic duties.

However, there is no explicit mention of a specific threshold or percentage of workload that must be dedicated to teaching/service before pursuing additional research.

## Question
[Policy #201b](https://policy.rice.edu/201b)

For non-tenure-track faculty, how do the academic freedom protections differ from those of tenure-track professors? Are there any special considerations or constraints applied to their classroom speech or research activities?

options.text:
The search results do not provide specific information on how academic freedom protections for non-tenure-track faculty differ from those of tenure-track professors. They do, however, outline general principles of academic freedom and the responsibilities associated with it, which apply broadly to all faculty members.

Academic freedom is a fundamental principle that supports free inquiry, teaching, and extramural utterance, and it is essential for the academic enterprise. It allows faculty members to pursue research and express their ideas without fear of censorship or retribution, provided they adhere to certain responsibilities and self-restraint.

For tenure-track faculty, academic freedom includes full freedom in research and publication, freedom in classroom discussions related to their subject, and freedom from institutional censorship when speaking or writing as citizens. However, the search results do not explicitly state whether these protections are different for non-tenure-track faculty.

Regarding classroom speech and research activities, the search results do not mention any special considerations or constraints specifically applied to non-tenure-track faculty. The general expectation is that all faculty members, regardless of tenure status, should exercise appropriate restraint, show respect for the opinions of others, and make efforts to indicate that they are not speaking for the institution when expressing personal views.

In summary, while the search results emphasize the importance of academic freedom for all faculty members, they do not provide detailed information on any differences in protections or constraints between tenure-track and non-tenure-track faculty. Therefore, it is unclear if there are specific distinctions in the application of academic freedom principles to non-tenure-track faculty based on the provided snippets.

According to the provided documents, non-tenure-track faculty members are not protected by tenure and therefore do not enjoy the same level of academic freedom as tenure-track professors. However, they are still entitled to express themselves freely in their roles as teachers and scholars.

The policy notes that adequate cause for dismissal must be related directly and substantially to the fitness of faculty members in their professional capacities as teachers or scholars, but it does not explicitly state how this applies differently to non-tenure-track faculty.

## Question
[Policy #201c](https://policy.rice.edu/201c)

For associate professors being considered for promotion to full professor, what is the process if the department review committee votes against promotion but the dean believes the candidate is qualified?

options.text: If the department review committee votes against the promotion of an associate professor to full professor, but the dean believes the candidate is qualified, the dean has the authority to request that the full promotion process proceed despite the department's decision. The dean will forward the dossier to the Promotion and Tenure Committee (P&T Committee) along with a confidential letter of recommendation supporting the candidate's promotion.

If the department's review committee votes against promoting an associate professor to full professor, but the dean believes the candidate is qualified, the dean may request that the full promotion process proceed. This decision should be documented in the departmental record and the dean informed of this process and its results.

## Question
[Policy #201c](https://policy.rice.edu/201c)

If an external reviewer for a tenure case has previously collaborated with the candidate, how should their relationship be disclosed and what weight is given to their letter?

options.text:
If an external reviewer for a tenure case has previously collaborated with the candidate, their relationship should be clearly disclosed in the review process. The letter from such a reviewer should include a description of any prior or existing relationship with the candidate. 

Although collaborators have an inherent conflict of interest in the promotion and tenure process, they may still offer important relevant information about the candidate that can inform the decision process. Therefore, letters from collaborators are included in the dossier but do not count towards the minimum requirement of six external review letters, of which at least four should be from persons suggested by the department. 

The department must identify any relationship and explain why it is beneficial or necessary to use those persons as reviewers. The final list of external reviewers, including those with potential conflicts of interest, must be approved by the dean.

Disclosures regarding prior relationships with the candidate must be made by external reviewers. However, the documents do not specify the weight given to such letters or provide guidance on how to evaluate them in the context of a tenure case.

## Question
[Policy #201c](https://policy.rice.edu/201c)

For candidates hired at an advanced rank like associate or full professor, what is the expedited process for their tenure review at Rice?

options.text: For candidates hired at an advanced rank, such as associate or full professor, Rice University has an expedited process for their tenure review. This process is conducted on an ad hoc basis and can occur at any time of the year to speed up the recruitment process. The preparation of the case follows the same guidelines as for normal reviews. Once the case is forwarded to the provost's office, the Promotion and Tenure (P&T) Committee reviews it and may choose to vote via email. If any member of the Committee feels it is necessary, a meeting of the P&T Committee will be called. After the review is concluded, the provost forwards the dossier to the president along with their recommendation and the P&T Committee's vote.

For candidates hired at an advanced rank like associate or full professor, the expedited process for their tenure review at Rice involves an interim review for tenure that can occur at any time of the year. The process follows the same guidelines as normal reviews and is conducted on an ad hoc basis. The Promotion and Tenure Committee reviews each case, which may include a vote via email. If necessary, a meeting will be called to discuss the review. Once concluded, the provost forwards the dossier to the president with their recommendation and the P&T Committee's vote.

## Question
[Policy #201c](https://policy.rice.edu/201c)

For an assistant professor's tenure case, how does the department determine which potential external reviewers to solicit letters from?

options.text:
The department determines which potential external reviewers to solicit letters from through a collaborative process involving both the department and the candidate. Here are the steps involved:

1. **Initial Lists Creation**: The department first compiles its own list of potential external reviewers without any knowledge of the candidate's list. This list is developed in consultation with the department faculty.

2. **Candidate's List**: The candidate is then asked to provide a list of potential external reviewers. This list includes individuals without a personal or professional conflict of interest, as well as collaborators, former advisors, and supervisors.

3. **Merging Lists**: Once the department's list is complete, it is merged with the candidate's list. Any names that overlap are designated as "department, also candidate" and count toward the minimum number of four letters from reviewers suggested by the department.

4. **Final Selection**: The chair consults with the dean to discuss the final selection of external reviewers. The final list must be approved by the dean. The selection aims to ensure a balance between the number of department-specified and candidate-specified reviewers.

5. **Conflict of Interest Considerations**: External reviewers should be chosen from recognized leading scholars in the candidate's field and should normally be from programs or departments of comparable quality to Rice. If it is necessary to use individuals with a potential conflict of interest, the department must identify the relationship and explain why it is beneficial or necessary to use those persons.

6. **Diversity of Expertise**: In cases where a candidate's work involves more than one sub-field or discipline, it is critical that the reviewers provide a range of expertise that matches the candidate’s interdisciplinary content.

By following these steps, the department ensures that the selection of external reviewers is thorough, balanced, and fair, providing a comprehensive evaluation of the candidate's qualifications for tenure.

The department first compiles its own list of potential external reviewers in consultation with the candidate. Once complete, the department requests a list of potential reviewers from the candidate, and then selects reviewers from both lists, ensuring balance between the number of department-specified and candidate-specified reviewers. Any overlapping names are designated as "department, also candidate" and count towards the minimum requirement. The final selection is discussed with the dean to ensure agreement on the selection of external reviewers.

## Question
[Policy #201c](https://policy.rice.edu/201c)

If new updates like publications or grants arise during an ongoing promotion review, how are those materials incorporated into the candidate's dossier?

options.text: If new updates such as publications or grants arise during an ongoing promotion review, these "late" materials are included in the candidate's dossier by forwarding them through the chair, dean, and provost to the Promotion and Tenure (P&T) Committee. The P&T Committee will decide at its discretion when to cut off the inclusion of updated materials. This decision will be communicated to the candidate through the dean and chair.

According to university policy, if a candidate receives notification of new publications or grants after the initial submission of their dossier, these "late" materials can be included by forwarding them through the chair, dean, and provost to the P&T Committee. The P&T Committee will decide at its discretion when to stop accepting updated materials, and this decision will be communicated to the candidate through the dean and chair.

## Question
[Policy #201d](https://policy.rice.edu/201d)

For consideration for promotion from Assistant to Associate Teaching Professor, is it required that the candidate has published pedagogical research or developed course materials like textbooks?

options.text: For promotion from Assistant to Associate Teaching Professor, it is not strictly required that the candidate has published pedagogical research or developed course materials like textbooks. However, the candidate must have a record of professional activity that brings current knowledge of the discipline and educational pedagogy into the classroom. This record may include, but is not limited to, pedagogical research, development and/or assessment of pedagogical practices, professional development, creative work relevant to the discipline, curriculum development, and/or innovative pedagogical practices.

According to the provided documents, there is no requirement for a candidate to have published pedagogical research or developed course materials like textbooks for consideration for promotion from Assistant to Associate Teaching Professor.

The document specifies that evidence of professional activity bringing current knowledge of the discipline and educational pedagogy into the classroom can include "but is not limited to" certain activities such as pedagogical research, development, and/or assessment of pedagogical practices. This suggests that other forms of professional activity can be considered, but it does not explicitly require publication or development of specific materials.

Therefore, while these activities may be examples of the type of professional activity expected for promotion, they are not specified as requirements.

## Question
[Policy #201d](https://policy.rice.edu/201d)

For promotion cases, is it required that external reviewer letters be solicited? Or are these optional?

options.text: For promotion cases, it is required that external reviewer letters be solicited. If an Assistant Teaching Professor receives a negative outcome in their 3rd year enhanced performance review, can they still be reappointed and continue on the tenure track past their 6th year?

options.text:
If an Assistant Teaching Professor receives a negative outcome in their 3rd year enhanced performance review, it is unlikely that they will be reappointed and continue on the tenure track past their 6th year. The enhanced performance review in the third year is a critical assessment of the assistant teaching professor’s trajectory toward promotion to associate teaching professor. A written document summarizing this review must be shared with the reviewee, the Dean, and the Provost.

For reappointment, assistant teaching professors must demonstrate a record of consistently excellent teaching, knowledge and application of evidence-based pedagogical practices, contributions to pedagogy at the department level, and service at the department level. If these criteria are not met, reappointment is unlikely.

Additionally, the formal appointment letters for additional contracts specify that assistant teaching professors must be promoted to associate teaching professor by the end of the sixth year or be removed from the teaching professor ranks. Therefore, a negative outcome in the 3rd year review would likely hinder their ability to meet the necessary criteria for reappointment and promotion, making it improbable for them to continue on the tenure track past their 6th year.

According to Policy 214 "Faculty Performance Reviews" and the Procedures for Faculty Reappointments, Promotions, and Tenure (201C), a reappointment review occurs in the third year of an assistant professor's contract. This process determines whether the person should be reappointed for a second four-year contract or if the appointment should be terminated.

However, there is no mention of an "enhanced performance review" in the provided documents, so it is unclear how this relates to the reappointment review.

In any case, the document states that the decision to award a second four-year contract involves evaluating the candidate's performance in categories similar to those used for tenure reviews. If an assistant professor receives a negative outcome in their third year evaluation, this may be considered during the reappointment review process.

It is worth noting that if an assistant professor is not reappointed, they can still receive one full year of employment following the review (the fourth year of the initial contract), but they cannot be appointed to any other tenure-track faculty rank.

The external reviewers should be chosen from among the recognized leading scholars in the candidate's field. For appointments/promotion at the rank of associate research professor, candidates must demonstrate eligibility criteria listed in Policy 201. ## Question
[Policy #202](https://policy.rice.edu/202)

What is the process for recommending a current faculty member for an endowed professorship? Who needs to approve it?

options.text:
The process for recommending a current faculty member for an endowed professorship at Rice University involves several steps and requires multiple levels of approval:

1. **Recommendation by the Dean**: The dean of the school consults with the school’s honorary title committee to suggest a faculty member for the endowed professorship.

2. **Provost and President Approval**: The dean's recommendation is then forwarded to the provost, who presents it to the president for approval.

3. **Board of Trustees Approval**: Finally, the recommendation must be approved by the Board of Trustees of Rice University. If the Board approves the appointment, the provost informs the awardee in writing.

Thus, the approval process involves the dean, the provost, the president, and ultimately the Board of Trustees.

The process for recommending a current faculty member for an endowed professorship involves the dean consulting with the school's honorary title committee for its suggestion of a faculty member. The provost then presents this recommendation to the president for approval, which is ultimately subject to approval by the Board of Trustees.

## Question
[Policy #202](https://policy.rice.edu/202)

If concerns arise about a faculty member's performance while holding a distinguished professorship, what steps are taken to review and potentially withdraw the title?

options.text:
If concerns arise about a faculty member's performance while holding a distinguished professorship at Rice University, the following steps are taken to review and potentially withdraw the title:

1. **Initiation of Review**: If a regular departmental review or a formal complaint demonstrates a deficiency in the performance of a titleholder, the dean may charge the school’s honorary title committee to undertake a review and prepare a report for the dean.

2. **Committee Review**: The honorary title committee will review the performance of the titleholder. If the committee finds a deficiency in the performance, it will suggest a remediation plan for the titleholder to eliminate the deficiency and propose a reasonable timetable for improvement.

3. **Dean's Determination**: After reviewing the committee’s report and recommendations, the dean determines the remediation plan and informs the titleholder of the negative finding and the remediation plan.

4. **Provost Notification**: If, at the end of the remediation period, the dean finds the performance still to be deficient, the dean informs the provost in writing.

5. **Decision on Withdrawal**: The provost, after consultation with the president, decides whether to withdraw the title for distinguished professorships and informs the titleholder in writing.

6. **Appeal Process**: If the faculty member believes that the withdrawal is not appropriate due to infringement of their academic freedom or due to procedural objections, they have 30 days after the decision by the provost to request the convenor of Appeals and Grievances of the Faculty Senate to form a review committee. This committee will consist of three tenured members of the faculty holding honorary titles, who will carry out an inquiry and submit their confidential recommendations to the president. The president makes the final decision and informs the faculty member of the final disposition of the honorary title.

Once a title is withdrawn, the titleholder must cease using it on all official communications but may still denote the dates the title was held on a CV.

If concerns arise about a faculty member's performance while holding a distinguished professorship, a regular departmental review or formal complaint demonstrates a deficiency. The dean then charges a committee formed of senior faculty members to undertake a review and prepare a report for the provost. If the committee finds a deficiency, it suggests a remediation plan, which the provost reviews and determines. If the performance still remains deficient at the end of the remediation period, the provost may decide to withdraw the title after consultation with the president, who makes the final decision. The faculty member is informed in writing.

## Question
[Policy #202](https://policy.rice.edu/202)

Are there any differences in how university professorships are awarded compared to endowed or distinguished professorships?

options.text:
Yes, there are differences in how university professorships are awarded compared to endowed or distinguished professorships at Rice University.

1. **Approval Process**:
   - **Endowed Professorships**: The awarding of an endowed professorship requires approval by the Board of Trustees of Rice University. The process involves the dean consulting with the school’s honorary title committee, which recommends a faculty member to the provost. The provost then presents the recommendation to the president for approval and transmission to the Board for final approval.
   - **Distinguished Professorships**: The awarding of a distinguished professorship does not require approval by the Board. The dean consults with the school’s honorary title committee, which recommends a faculty member to the provost. The provost then presents the recommendation to the president for approval.
   - **University Professorships**: The awarding of a university professorship requires approval by the Board. The recommendation process is usually initiated by the provost, who informs the awardee in writing.

2. **Eligibility**:
   - **Endowed Professorships**: Faculty members in both the tenure-track and the non-tenure-track faculty ranks may be eligible for endowed chairs, depending upon the conditions in the particular endowment.
   - **Distinguished Professorships**: Faculty members in both the tenure-track and the non-tenure-track faculty ranks may be eligible for distinguished professorships.
   - **University Professorships**: Only full professors may be eligible for university professorships.

3. **Scope and Terms of Appointment**:
   - **Endowed Professorships**: The title is usually in addition to and separable from the individual’s faculty appointment. It is subject to any provisions and conditions that may be attached to the endowed fund.
   - **Distinguished Professorships**: The title is in addition to and separable from the individual’s faculty appointment. It is usually awarded for a fixed term and may expire, be renewed, or be withdrawn.
   - **University Professorships**: The title usually remains with the faculty member throughout their career at Rice or unless it is withdrawn. It allows the titleholder to teach in any department at Rice.

These differences highlight the distinct processes and criteria involved in awarding these prestigious titles at Rice University.

Yes, there is a difference in the awarding process for university professorships compared to endowed and distinguished professorships. University professorships require approval by the Board, whereas endowed and distinguished professorships do not. Specifically, the awarding of a university professorship involves the provost informing the awardee in writing after recommendation by the Board, whereas awarding an endowed or distinguished professorship involves consultation with the school's honorary title committee and then presenting it to the president for approval, also followed by written notification from the provost.

If a faculty member needs to take medical leave for surgery and recovery, how is their salary handled during the leave period?

options.text:
If a faculty member needs to take medical leave for surgery and recovery, their salary during the leave period is handled as follows:

1. **Short-Term Disability (STD) Leave**: Faculty members who are benefits-eligible may request personal medical leaves for any medical reason, including surgery and recovery. During this period, they may receive up to 50 percent of their academic year salary based on the length of their leave under short-term disability. After the short-term disability period, continuing disability payment at partial salary may be requested and approved under the university's long-term disability insurance program.

2. **Salary Continuation**: For the first 8 weeks of an approved STD leave, the faculty member receives 100% of their regular salary. From week 9 and beyond, the salary is reduced to 80% of their regular salary.

Faculty members are expected to apply through their departments to Human Resources for short-term disability leave benefits, where appropriate, to pay for salary continuation.

According to policy, if a faculty member on medical leave receives short-term disability payments, they may receive up to 50 percent of their academic year salary based on the length of their leave. If not covered by short-term disability, continuing disability payment at partial salary may be requested and approved under the University's long-term disability insurance program.

options.text: If a faculty member needs to interrupt their sabbatical for personal reasons, the policy does not explicitly address the implications for their return to service requirement. However, it is clear that as a condition of taking a sabbatical leave, the faculty member must return to the University and continue to fulfill their professional responsibilities for a specified period. Specifically, a sabbatical leave that draws down 15 or fewer semester-service credits requires at least one full year of return to service, while a sabbatical leave drawing down 16 or more semester-service credits requires a two-year return to service.

The documents do not explicitly address interruptions to sabbatical leave due to personal reasons. If a faculty member needs to interrupt their sabbatical for personal reasons unrelated to these goals, it is unclear how this would impact their return to service requirement. The policy emphasizes the importance of satisfactory performance and productivity in scholarship, creative activity, and teaching as conditions for approval and renewal of sabbatical leave. Therefore, any interruption due to personal reasons might be considered against the purpose of the sabbatical, but this would need to be explicitly addressed in further documentation or by consultation with relevant authorities to determine any potential implications for their return to service requirement.

options.text: No, there are no provisions in the policy for 'banking' accumulated sabbatical credits beyond the 24 semester maximum. The policy explicitly states that the maximum allowed accumulation is 24 semesters of sabbatical-service credit, and absent exceptional circumstances requiring the approval of the President or Provost, no service credit in excess of 24 semesters will be allowed.

According to the policy, faculty members are initially credited with the semesters of actually accumulated sabbatical credit, not to exceed twelve (12), unless an explicit exception was already granted, in writing, before the publication of this policy. This suggests that accumulated sabbatical credits can be "banked" beyond the 24 semester maximum for a period of time after the policy's implementation. However, it is unclear what happens to these excess credits if they remain unused for an extended period or when a faculty member finally takes their sabbatical leave.

## Question
[Policy #216](https://policy.rice.edu/216)

If a faculty member takes on a consulting role for a company that has licensed their Rice-developed technology, what are the key considerations and requirements under this policy?

options.text:
If a faculty member at Rice University takes on a consulting role for a company that has licensed their Rice-developed technology, there are several key considerations and requirements under the university's policies:

1. **Disclosure of Outside Activities**: The faculty member must fully disclose their consulting activities to Rice University in advance. This includes updating disclosures as relationships evolve and ensuring transparency with department chairs and supervisors.

2. **Management of Conflicts of Interest (COI)**: Consulting for a company that has licensed the faculty member's Rice-developed technology is considered a manageable conflict of interest. However, it requires additional review and management to mitigate risks. The faculty member must ensure that their consulting activities do not conflict with their institutional responsibilities or other obligations to Rice University.

3. **Legal Agreements**: The faculty member must ensure that a legal agreement is in place to address any potential intersection of intellectual property between Rice and the outside entity. This includes the inclusion of the Rice Addendum to Faculty Consulting or Related Agreement as an addendum to the consulting agreement.

4. **Impact on Institutional Responsibilities**: The consulting activities should not impair the faculty member's ability to perform their institutional responsibilities for Rice or fully enjoy academic freedom. They should consider how restrictions on the flow of information may affect their or their students' ability to participate in the free discourse of scholarship.

5. **Special Considerations**: The Faculty Conflicts Committee (FCC) will likely consider the conflict of interest manageable and work with the faculty member to mitigate the risk. This includes ensuring that the consulting activities do not undermine Rice University's basic missions of education and research.

6. **Use of University Resources**: If the consulting activities involve the use of university personnel, students, facilities, or materials, appropriate contractual agreements and prior written approval by the FCC and the Executive Vice President for Research are required.

By adhering to these considerations and requirements, the faculty member can ensure that their consulting role aligns with Rice University's policies and maintains the integrity of their institutional responsibilities.

To take on a consulting role for a company that has licensed Rice-developed technology, a faculty member must consider the following:

The faculty member's consulting activities must be disclosed to Rice University in advance. The Rice Addendum to Faculty Consulting or Related Agreement must be included as an addendum to the faculty's consulting agreement with the outside entity.

Additionally, the faculty member must ensure that their consulting agreement does not conflict with their Institutional Responsibilities or other obligations to Rice University and are consistent with Rice University policies.

The faculty member should also consider ensuring transparency with department chairs and supervisors, considering impacts to students (including effective mentoring and advising), and obtaining a legal agreement in place in the event of any potential intersection of intellectual property between Rice and the outside entity.

## Question
[Policy #216](https://policy.rice.edu/216)

Can students be involved in a faculty member's outside business activities or startups? If so, what safeguards does the policy require?

options.text:
Yes, students can be involved in a faculty member's outside business activities or startups under certain conditions. The policy requires several safeguards to ensure that the involvement does not negatively impact the students' educational experience or create conflicts of interest.

1. **Disclosure**: The arrangement must be disclosed on the Scholar’s Conflict of Interest (COI) disclosure form, and the business interest must be disclosed to the student.

2. **Prioritizing Student's Academic Duties**: Scholars must prioritize the student's academic duties and rights while avoiding conflicts. This is particularly important if the Scholar holds a supervisory or advisory role over the student.

3. **Management Plan**: Additional requirements may be detailed in the Management Plan, such as requiring disclosure to the student, periodic meetings with the dean’s office or department, or assigning a co-advisor.

4. **Student Rights**: Students have the right to discuss their concerns about potential conflicts with their deans’ offices, the Office of Research Integrity, and anonymously through the Ethics Line. They may also request to be placed on a different research project not impacted by the potential conflict, although this is subject to the availability of substitute projects and suitable funding.

5. **Protection from Retaliation**: Throughout this process, students are protected from retaliation in accordance with Rice policies.

These safeguards are designed to ensure that the educational success of students is not compromised by their involvement in a faculty member's outside business activities or startups.

Yes, students can be involved in a faculty member's outside business activities or start-ups, but with certain conditions. According to policy F, if the arrangement is disclosed on the Scholar's COI disclosure form and the business interest is disclosed to the student, then students may be involved. Additionally, the FCC may assist Scholars and students in clarifying expectations at any time during the relationship.

In cases where there may be a risk of an actual or potential conflict of interest, such as when the faculty member has an Outside Interest in an entity that also licenses intellectual property owned by Rice (as discussed in policy D), a Management Plan is required. This plan may include requirements like disclosure to the student, periodic meetings with the dean's office or department, or assigning a co-advisor.

It appears that the University encourages entrepreneurship and start-up activities among faculty members, but prioritizes the preservation of students' rights as stated in Section IV.G. Students are not allowed to enter into contracts on behalf of the university without approval from the Dean of Undergraduates or their designees (policy 8).

If a faculty member serves as a principal investigator on both a Rice research project and a related project for an outside company they have a financial interest in, does that situation present a conflict of interest? How should it be managed?

options.text:
Yes, if a faculty member serves as a principal investigator on both a Rice research project and a related project for an outside company in which they have a financial interest, this situation presents a conflict of interest (COI). This is because the faculty member would be in a position to influence both the Rice portion of the award and the outside entity’s portion of the award, which creates the risk of an actual or perceived COI.

To manage this conflict of interest, a Management Plan must be enacted prior to the commencement of the research activities or the exchange of funding. This process involves disclosing the COI and obtaining approval for a Management Plan that outlines how the conflict will be mitigated and managed. The Management Plan should describe the conflict, create an explicit agreement between the faculty member and Rice to manage the conflict, and facilitate oversight of the conflict.

Yes, this situation presents a Conflict of Interest (COI). According to the policy documents, if a Scholar holds the title of Principal Investigator on a Rice award and also has an Outside Interest in the same project or related projects, a COI exists. This is specifically stated when "a Scholar controls both the Rice portion of the award as well as the Outside Entity’s portion of the award".

To manage this conflict, an approved Management Plan must be created to mitigate the risk of actual or perceived COI.

1. Negotiating with the University on behalf of an Outside Entity in which the Scholar has an Outside Interest.
2. Negotiating on behalf of the University with an Outside Entity in which the Scholar has an Outside Interest.
3. Executing an assignment agreement where the intellectual property (IP) assignment term conflicts with the IP terms of the University, their sponsored Research, or a federal grant involving the same or related technology.
